Cockatoos

Red-Vented Cockatoo

Also known as the Philippine Cockatoo, this is a critically endangered species. It is an all-white cockatoo with a helmet-like crest and distinctive reddish-orange feathers under the tail.

Origin
Australia & Oceania
Size
12 inches (30.5 cm). Weight: 280-350g (10-12.3 oz)
Weight
315g avg.
Noise Level
Loud. They have a loud, raucous call typical of cockatoos.

Looking for a Red-Vented Cockatoo?

See Available Red-Vented Cockatoo Listings

Species Ratings

Talking Ability 1/10
Noise Level 7/10
Social Needs 7/10
Cuddliness 5/10

Temperament & Personality

Intelligent, social, and playful. Due to their rarity, most are in conservation programs rather than the pet trade. They require significant social interaction.

Vocalization & Talking Ability

Can learn to talk, but their numbers are so low that their primary vocalizations are their natural calls.

Dietary Needs

A varied diet including seeds, fruits, flowers, and nuts. Their specific dietary needs are a focus of conservation breeding efforts.

Health & Lifespan

Lifespan of up to 40 years. Critically endangered due to habitat loss and poaching. They are not available as pets.

Housing Requirements

Housed in specialized aviaries for breeding and conservation purposes. Not a pet species.

Common Questions About Red-Vented Cockatoo

What is the lifespan of a Red-Vented Cockatoo?

The Red-Vented Cockatoo typically lives for Up to 40 years. With proper care, diet, and regular vet check-ups, they can live a full and healthy life.

Is the Red-Vented Cockatoo good for beginners?

This species is rated as 'advanced' care level. They require specific attention, socialization, or dietary needs that may challenge first-time owners.

Where does the Red-Vented Cockatoo come from?

The Red-Vented Cockatoo is native to Australia & Oceania.

More Cockatoos

Bare-Eyed Cockatoo

Loud. While maybe not as deafening as a Moluccan, they have a very loud call and enjoy using it, especially in the morning and evening.

Citron-Crested Cockatoo

Very Loud. Possess the classic, ear-splitting cockatoo screech, especially when excited or demanding attention.
